questions.text: An Industrial worker was admitted in the hospital with injury to the eye following his work with hammer & chisel, with suspected foreign body in eye. Which of the following investigations will be detrimental?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging).

MRI utilizes powerful magnetic fields to generate images. If a ferromagnetic metallic foreign body is present within or near the eye, exposure to these strong magnetic fields can cause the foreign body to move, twist, or dislodge. Such movement can lead to catastrophic damage to delicate ocular structures, including the retina, optic nerve, lens, or blood vessels, potentially causing further hemorrhage, inflammation, or even blindness. Additionally, metallic objects can heat up during an MRI scan, leading to thermal injury. Therefore, MRI is strongly contraindicated when a ferromagnetic intraocular foreign body is suspected until its presence and nature are ruled out by safer imaging modalities.

questions.text: 35 years old male, expansile swelling of distal forearm, near wrist ajoint. Xray Shown
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

GCT

The clinical presentation of a 35-year-old male with an expansile swelling near the distal forearm close to the wrist joint, combined with the radiographic features shown, is characteristic of a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT). GCT typically occurs in adults between 20 to 40 years of age and involves the epiphysis of long bones. The distal radius is a common location. Radiologically, GCT presents as an eccentric, expansile, lytic lesion often extending to the articular surface without sclerotic margins, as seen in the X-ray provided. The soft tissue swelling and thinning of the cortex seen in the image further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: Patient comes to you with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Putty Kidney

The X-ray displays extensive, dense, and amorphous calcification in the region of one of the kidneys (appearing on the anatomical right, which is the left side of the image as conventionally viewed if the "R" marker is for the patient's right side). This appearance, where the kidney is essentially replaced by caseous, calcified material, giving it a putty-like consistency and appearance on imaging, is characteristic of end-stage renal tuberculosis. Renal tuberculosis is a common cause of "sterile pyuria," which means there are white blood cells in the urine, but routine bacterial cultures are negative; this occurs because Mycobacterium tuberculosis requires special culture techniques and does not grow on standard media. Abdominal or flank pain can also be a symptom of renal tuberculosis. Thus, the combination of clinical symptoms (abdominal pain, sterile pyuria) and the classic radiological appearance strongly points towards a putty kidney secondary to tuberculosis.

questions.text: Patient with Fatigue, 12 year old child. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Supracardiac TAPVC-Snowman.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) is a congenital heart defect where all four pulmonary veins abnormally drain into the right atrium or veins leading to it, instead of the left atrium. In the supracardiac type, the pulmonary veins typically connect to a common vertical vein, which then drains into the innominate (brachiocephalic) vein and subsequently into the superior vena cava (SVC). This anomalous venous pathway causes the SVC and the vertical vein to dilate, creating a widened superior mediastinal shadow that forms the "head" of the snowman. The enlarged heart, resulting from right-sided volume overload due to the shunting of the entire pulmonary venous return to the right side, forms the "body" of the snowman. The increased pulmonary blood flow (pulmonary plethora) often seen with TAPVC is also consistent with the radiographic findings. Fatigue is a plausible symptom in a child with this condition due to inefficient circulation and potential cyanosis or heart failure.

questions.text: Middle aged man with 2 year history of backache in morning and history of redness of eye.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ankylosing Spondylitis

The patient presents with a two-year history of backache that is worse in the morning, a characteristic feature of inflammatory back pain commonly seen in ankylosing spondylitis (AS). This type of pain typically improves with activity and worsens with rest. Furthermore, the history of redness of the eye is highly suggestive of uveitis or iritis, which is a common extra-articular manifestation associated with AS. The provided X-ray of the lumbosacral spine and pelvis demonstrates significant changes in the sacroiliac (SI) joints. There appears to be bilateral sacroiliitis, characterized by irregularity, haziness, sclerosis (increased bone density), and likely partial or complete fusion (ankylosis) of these joints. Bilateral sacroiliitis is a hallmark radiological feature of ankylosing spondylitis and is often one of the earliest and most definitive signs of the disease.

questions.text: Which part of the bowel is dilated in the Xray shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Jejunum

The X-ray shown displays multiple dilated loops of bowel predominantly in the central part of the abdomen. The key feature identifying the dilated segment is the presence of valvulae conniventes (also known as plicae circulares), which are mucosal folds that characteristically extend all the way across the lumen of the bowel. These folds are relatively closely spaced and prominent in the dilated loops visible in the image, giving a classic "stack of coins" or "coiled spring" appearance. This specific appearance, particularly the closely packed and prominent circumferential folds, is most characteristic of dilated B. Jejunum. The jejunum constitutes the middle part of the small intestine, and its numerous valvulae conniventes are a distinguishing feature that helps differentiate it from other parts of the bowel on radiographic studies, especially when dilated due to obstruction or other pathology.

questions.text: Identify the finding seen:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diverticulosis

The image provided is from a contrast study, likely a barium enema, showing a segment of the colon. The most striking finding is the presence of multiple, well-defined, flask-shaped or rounded outpouchings extending from the lumen of the colonic wall. This appearance is characteristic of B. Diverticulosis. Diverticulosis is a common condition where small pouches, called diverticula, develop in the wall of the colon, most frequently in the sigmoid colon. On a barium enema, these diverticula fill with contrast material and are clearly visualized as protrusions extending beyond the normal contour of the bowel lumen, as seen in the image. The presence of these multiple outpouchings is the hallmark of colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text: Child with normal bone mineralization. Xray shown
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Scurvy

The X-ray shows characteristic features suggestive of Scurvy, which is caused by vitamin C deficiency. Importantly, the bone mineralization is preserved, as mentioned in the question, helping to differentiate it from conditions like rickets. Radiological features of scurvy include a dense white line of provisional calcification at the metaphysis (Frankel’s line), a zone of rarefaction beneath it (Trümmerfeld zone), a corner sign or Pelkan spur (metaphyseal beaking), and a “scorbutic zone” that appears lucent. The cortex may also appear thin, and there may be evidence of subperiosteal hemorrhage. These signs are evident in the X-ray provided, supporting the diagnosis of scurvy in a child with otherwise normal bone mineralization.

questions.text: Child playing left unattended by the mother. Develops difficulty swallowing. No distress. CXR shown. Where is the foreign body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Esophagus

This conclusion is supported by both the clinical presentation and the radiographic findings. The child developed difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), which is a primary symptom indicating an obstruction or irritation within the esophagus. The chest X-rays provide definitive evidence: in the anteroposterior (AP) view, the coin appears "en face" (as a full circle), and in the lateral view, it appears "on edge" (as a thin line). This specific orientation is classic for a flat foreign body lodged in the esophagus; due to the structure of the esophageal musculature, flat objects tend to align themselves in the coronal plane. Furthermore, on the lateral view, the foreign body is situated posterior to the air-filled shadow of the trachea and anterior to the vertebral column, which is the anatomical location of the esophagus. The reported lack of respiratory distress is also more consistent with an esophageal foreign body than one in the airway.

questions.text: 12 year old with chronic ear discharge, fever. CT scan is shown what is the complication shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Temporal lobe abscess

The clinical presentation of a 12-year-old with chronic ear discharge (suggestive of Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media - CSOM) and fever raises strong suspicion for an intracranial complication. CSOM can lead to the spread of infection to adjacent structures, with the temporal lobe and cerebellum being common sites for brain abscess formation. The provided axial CT scan shows an area of low attenuation (hypodensity) within the right temporal lobe, which is consistent with cerebritis (inflammation of brain tissue) or an early brain abscess, even without contrast administration (which would typically show ring enhancement in a mature abscess). The temporal lobe's proximity to the middle ear and mastoid makes it a frequent location for otogenic brain abscesses. Symptoms like fever are indicative of an active infection, and an abscess is a serious infectious complication.

questions.text: Patient started on Radiotherapy for cancer, least affected by radiation exposure is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Neurons in the Brainws

The sensitivity of cells to radiation is generally governed by the Law of Bergonié and Tribondeau, which states that cells are more radiosensitive if they are actively dividing (high mitotic rate), undifferentiated, and have a long mitotic future. Mature neurons in the adult brain are highly differentiated, specialized cells that are largely post-mitotic, meaning they do not typically undergo cell division. Due to this low rate of cell turnover and high degree of differentiation, nervous tissue, particularly mature neurons, is relatively radioresistant compared to tissues with rapidly proliferating cell populations. While high doses of radiation can still cause significant long-term damage to the brain, including radiation necrosis or cognitive impairment, the acute cell-killing effect is less pronounced in mature neurons compared to the other options listed.

questions.text: Patient with untreated Spinal TB developed a swelling in the Left groin following which his left limb was in flexion and Internal Rotation. Which of the marked muscle responsible for the attitude of his limb?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

4 shows Psoas

The patient's history of untreated spinal tuberculosis (TB) leading to a swelling in the left groin is highly suggestive of a psoas abscess. A psoas abscess occurs when an infection from the spine (like TB) tracks down along the psoas muscle sheath. Irritation or inflammation of the psoas muscle (a condition known as psoasitis, often caused by the abscess) leads the patient to adopt a posture that minimizes pain by reducing stretch on this muscle. The psoas major muscle is a primary flexor of the hip. Therefore, irritation of this muscle will typically cause the hip to be held in flexion. Looking at the provided coronal CT scan and the numbered labels, the structure labeled 4 clearly represents the Left Psoas Muscle. Thus, the most appropriate marked muscle responsible for the flexion component of the limb's attitude is the psoas muscle. While the psoas major also contributes to external rotation of the hip, the clinical scenario of a psoas abscess most prominently explains the hip flexion. The internal rotation component mentioned in the question might be due to complex pain-related posturing, secondary muscle spasm, or involvement of adjacent structures, but the flexion is a direct consequence of psoas irritation.

questions.text: Non-contrast CT Brain: Sudden onset severe headache. What does the image show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Subarachnoid haemorrhage

This diagnosis is indicated by the presence of high attenuation material (which appears white on a CT scan and represents acute blood) within the normally dark, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)-filled subarachnoid spaces. Specifically, hyperdensity can be seen filling the basal cisterns (such as the suprasellar, interpeduncular, and ambient cisterns) and extending into the Sylvian fissures and sulci over the surface of the brain. This distribution of blood, outlining the brain's surface and its cisterns, is the characteristic radiographic appearance of a subarachnoid haemorrhage. The clinical history of a sudden onset severe headache ("thunderclap headache") is also highly suggestive of this condition, which is often caused by a ruptured cerebral aneurysm.

choices.text: Immediately shift the patient to OT for thoracotomy
Immediate needle thoracotomy in the 5th intercostal space
Large bore needle in 5th Intercostal space followed by ICD tube in 5th Intercostal space

questions.text: 25 year old male came to emergency after Road traffic accident. He is unable to speak full sentences, with hyper-resonant note on percussion and hypotension. CXR is shown, what is the appropriate initial management of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Large bore needle in 5th intercostal space followed by ICD tube in 5th intercostal space.

The immediate priority is to relieve the tension by decompressing the pleural space. This is typically achieved by inserting a large-bore needle into the pleural cavity (needle thoracostomy or needle decompression), often in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior or mid-axillary line as per current ATLS guidelines (or the 2nd intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line traditionally). This rapidly converts the tension pneumothorax into a simple pneumothorax, allowing the lung to re-expand partially and, critically, relieving the pressure on the mediastinal structures, which improves venous return and cardiac output, thereby addressing the hypotension. Following this emergency needle decompression, a definitive chest tube (Intercostal Drain - ICD) must be inserted to allow for continuous drainage of air and full re-expansion of the lung. Option C describes this complete and appropriate sequence of initial management for a tension pneumothorax.

questions.text: All lung carcinomas for diagnosis requires CECT thorax but MRI is useful in which of the following -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pancoast tumour

While Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) of the thorax is a primary imaging modality for the diagnosis and initial staging of all lung carcinomas, MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) offers specific advantages and is particularly useful in the evaluation of D. Pancoast tumour. Pancoast tumors, also known as superior sulcus tumors, are located at the apex of the lung and are characterized by their tendency to invade adjacent structures. MRI, with its superior soft-tissue contrast resolution compared to CT, is exceptionally valuable in assessing the extent of these tumors. It can more accurately delineate tumor invasion into the chest wall (including ribs and vertebrae), the brachial plexus, subclavian vessels, and the neural foramina or spinal canal. This detailed information regarding local invasion is critical for determining resectability, planning complex surgical approaches, and guiding radiation therapy. Therefore, MRI plays a crucial role in the comprehensive evaluation and treatment planning for Pancoast tumors.

questions.text: Find below the contrast study and identify the investigation and possible diagnosis-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

RGU with bulbar stricture

The image displays a contrast study of the male urethra where contrast medium has been introduced retrogradely from the external urethral meatus. This type of investigation is known as a Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU). Upon examining the RGU, a significant narrowing or stricture is clearly visible within the anterior urethra. Based on its anatomical location – proximal to the penile urethra and in the segment that traverses the perineum before the urogenital diaphragm – this stricture is situated in the bulbar urethra. Therefore, the most appropriate identification of the investigation and possible diagnosis is A. RGU with bulbar stricture. Bulbar urethral strictures are common and can result from various causes including trauma (e.g., straddle injuries), infection, or iatrogenic injury.

questions.text: CT scan in this emergency patient shows:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lacunar infarction

The CT scan shown is an axial non-contrast view of the brain. The image primarily demonstrates bilateral, symmetrical hyperdense (bright) areas within the trigones (atria) of the lateral ventricles, which are characteristic of physiological calcification of the choroid plexus. Additionally, there may be calcification in the pineal gland region. These are common, age-related findings and are not in themselves pathological or typically the cause of an acute emergency. The brain parenchyma otherwise appears largely unremarkable on this slice, with no clear evidence of acute, large-scale hemorrhage or obvious mass effect.

Given the options, if we are to identify a pathology, we must look for subtle signs or consider common incidental findings in an "emergency patient" whose reason for the scan isn't specified beyond that context. Considering the options:

The most plausible answer, if a subtle or chronic pathology is implied or if other acute options are definitively absent, would be A. Lacunar infarction. Lacunar infarcts are small, old strokes that can be found incidentally on CT scans, especially in older individuals or those with vascular risk factors, who might present to an emergency department for various reasons. On a non-contrast CT, a chronic lacunar infarct would appear as a small, well-defined area of low attenuation (similar to cerebrospinal fluid density). While no definite lacunar infarct is unequivocally clear in this single image without further clinical information or higher resolution, it is a common incidental finding that fits the description of a discrete pathological entity. If other acute pathologies listed are clearly absent, this might be the intended answer representing a chronic or incidental finding.

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown on the CT scan
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Craniopharyngioma

Craniopharyngiomas are benign (WHO Grade I) epithelial tumors that typically arise in the sellar or suprasellar cistern from remnants of Rathke's pouch. On CT scans, they often present as mixed solid and cystic masses. Calcification is a very common feature, particularly in the adamantinomatous subtype (more common in children), and these calcifications appear hyperdense. The solid components can also appear isodense to hyperdense and typically enhance with contrast. Papillary craniopharyngiomas (more common in adults) may be more often solid or mixed solid-cystic and less frequently calcified, but can still exhibit hyperdense solid portions or some calcification. The suprasellar location, the well-defined nature, and the hyperdense appearance (suggesting either calcification, a dense solid component, or dense proteinaceous cyst contents) seen in the image are all consistent with a craniopharyngioma.

choices.text: Actively dividing cells are radio resistant
Small vessels are resistant to radiation
Radiation dose at a point is inversely proportional to the square of distance from the source
Gl Mucosa is one of the most radioresistant tissues in the GIT

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Radiation dose at a point is inversely proportional to the square of distance from the source.

This principle is known as the Inverse Square Law, which is a fundamental concept in radiation physics. It states that for a point source of radiation that emits radiation isotropically (equally in all directions), the intensity of the radiation (and consequently the dose received) at any given point decreases proportionally to the square of the distance from that source. For instance, if you double the distance from the radiation source, the radiation dose will be reduced to one-quarter (1/2²) of its original value, and if you triple the distance, the dose will be reduced to one-ninth (1/3²). This law is critical for understanding radiation exposure and for implementing radiation protection measures, such as maintaining distance from radiation sources.

questions.text: Mickey Mouse sign which of the following structures is not a Contributor on duplex scan
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Popliteal vein

The "Mickey Mouse sign" is a characteristic sonographic view obtained in the transverse plane at the level of the groin, specifically depicting the saphenofemoral junction. In this sign, the large Common Femoral Vein (CFV) forms the "face" of Mickey Mouse. The Great Saphenous Vein (GSV) joining the CFV anteromedially forms one of Mickey's "ears," and the Common Femoral Artery (CFA), positioned anterolateral or lateral to the CFV, typically forms the other "ear." The popliteal vein, however, is located much more distally in the leg, within the popliteal fossa behind the knee. Therefore, due to its distinct anatomical location, the popliteal vein is not a component of the "Mickey Mouse sign" visualized in the groin.

questions.text: Personal dose monitoring is done by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

TLD badge (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter badge).

TLD badges are passive radiation detection devices that are worn by individuals for a specified period (typically one to three months). They contain a crystalline material, such as lithium fluoride or calcium fluoride, which absorbs and stores energy when exposed to ionizing radiation. When the badge is processed, this material is heated, causing it to release the stored energy in the form of light. The intensity of the emitted light is directly proportional to the radiation dose received by the wearer. TLDs are widely used because they are relatively accurate, can measure a range of radiation doses and types (beta, gamma, X-rays), are reusable after annealing (though processing is usually done by specialized services), and provide a reliable record of an individual's cumulative radiation exposure for regulatory and safety purposes.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 51 year old with abdominal pain
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ureterocele.

In the region where one of the ureters (appearing more prominent on the patient's right, which is the left side of the image) enters the bladder, there is a distinct, round to oval filling defect that protrudes into the bladder lumen. This defect, often surrounded by a thin halo of contrast material, creates the characteristic "cobra head" or "spring onion" sign, which is pathognomonic for a ureterocele. A ureterocele is a cystic dilatation of the terminal intravesical (within the bladder) segment of the ureter, which can be associated with symptoms such as abdominal pain (as mentioned in the 51-year-old patient), urinary tract infections, or obstruction.

questions.text: What is the name of the structure marked by tip of arrow ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

IVC

The structure marked by the tip of the arrow in the CT image is the Inferior Vena Cava (IVC). The IVC is a large, thin-walled, venous structure seen anterior and slightly to the right of the vertebral body on axial CT images. It returns deoxygenated blood from the lower body to the heart. In contrast to the aorta, which has a thicker wall and is usually located to the left of the spine, the IVC appears more ovoid or crescentic due to its compressibility and is often located more to the right. The position and the radiologic density of the structure in this scan match those of the IVC, confirming this as the correct answer.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by arrows
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fornix

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that acts as a major output tract of the hippocampus. It is located in the midline just inferior to the corpus callosum and can be visualized on axial CT scans as a paired structure running between the lateral ventricles. In the given image, the arrows point to two thin, white, symmetrical lines near the midline, which are characteristic of the columns of the fornix. These structures are surrounded by cerebrospinal fluid in the lateral ventricles, making them more visible on a CT scan. The fornix plays a critical role in the limbic system, involved in memory formation and recall.

questions.text: Which of these structures is anechoic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cyst

"Anechoic" means without echoes, and such structures appear black on an ultrasound image. This appearance occurs because simple fluid, which typically fills a cyst, offers very little resistance to the passage of ultrasound waves and reflects minimal to no sound waves back to the transducer. Therefore, the fluid-filled lumen of a simple cyst (like a renal cyst, ovarian cyst, or a ganglion cyst) will appear black. Other sonographic features of a simple cyst often include well-defined, thin walls and posterior acoustic enhancement (increased echogenicity behind the cyst) due to the unimpeded passage of sound through the fluid.
